Virginia Giuffre recounts a lifetime of abuse in her memoir 'Nobody's Girl' 
         By Adriana Gallardo, Leila Fadel 
        
           Updated Thursday, October 23, 2025 • 1:15 PM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Morning Edition 
        
      

        
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Before the world knew her name, she was the teen girl in a pink top and shiny jeans embraced at her waist by the now disgraced Prince Andrew's arm. Behind them stood a smiling Ghislaine Maxwell, the longtime partner of the late Jeffrey Epstein. Epstein himself took the photo. Her name was Virginia Roberts Giuffre, one of the most public accusers of abuse by Epstein and the many powerful men Giuffre says she was trafficked to in the early 2000s. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Epstein was convicted in 2008 in Florida on charges related to soliciting prostitution. His 2019 federal sex-trafficking charges were dismissed after his death by suicide while awaiting trial in New York. Maxwell was later convicted of crimes related to the sexual abuse of minors and is serving a 20-year sentence in Texas. Days before the publication of Giuffre's memoir,  Nobody's Girl,  Buckingham Palace released a statement from Prince Andrew. It said he had agreed to give up his title as Duke of York amid fresh scrutiny of the allegations. In  Nobody's Girl , Giuffre says she first met Prince Andrew in 2001 and that he guessed correctly she was then 17 years old. "My daughters are just a little younger than you," she recalls him saying. "He was friendly enough, but still entitled — as if he believed having sex with me was his birthright," she wrote. Prince Andrew has consistently denied Giuffre's accusations. Epstein  reached a financial settlement  with Giuffre in 2009. Prince Andrew  later settled  with Giuffre in 2022. Giuffre died by suicide in April, at age 41, just months before her book's release. Her collaborator on  Nobody's Girl , author and journalist Amy Wallace, and Giuffre's younger brother, Sky Roberts, spoke about the memoir with  Morning Edition's  Leila Fadel. Here are five takeaways from the conversation.  1. Giuffre called her father "the original betrayer" The memoir begins with the abuse Giuffre said started when she was about 7 years old. Before calling out Epstein, Maxwell and their wealthy friends, Wallace said Giuffre wanted to name her "original betrayer." "When we began unpacking all of that, she had always said 'I was abused by a family friend,' and that was true as far as it went, but she had also been abused by her own father," Wallace said. "You have to understand Virginia's history… victims of sexual trafficking are not born, they are made, and they are made by terrible experiences that they have over years." Giuffre was 16 when she met Maxwell at Mar-a-Lago resort, where she worked as a locker room attendant in the spa. "And up to that point, the world that had been revealed to her, was a world in which adult men had sex with young girls, children, and didn't pay the price for it," Wallace added. Giuffre's father denies these accusations. 2. Her "toughest battle" came at home  Giuffre was married for over 20 years and had three children. Near the end of her life, she was estranged from her husband. Her brother said she had begun to speak openly about the domestic abuse she had allegedly experienced over the years. "She fought off Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, and she was very proud of that with her survivor sister. She wanted to continue that advocacy work. But I would say, the hardest fight of her battle was in her backyard with her husband, and she was a little embarrassed about that, as anybody would be coming forward," Roberts said. Giuffre's husband denies these allegations. 3. Her brothers were by her side before her death in Australia Earlier this year, Giuffre was recovering from a car crash and renal failure. Her brothers traveled to Australia to help care for her. "At one point, we had a jet lined up for her on a tarmac ready to bring her home so she could get medical treatment," Roberts shared. "We were with her in her final couple of weeks. And, you know, I was, I was, I was the one that found my sister." Having displayed so much strength facing the legal and public battles against Epstein and others, her brother says they thought she "would make it through because she'd pulled through so many times before." 4. Giuffre wanted the Epstein files released President Trump has not ruled out a pardon for Maxwell. "Well, I'll take a look at it. I'll speak to the DOJ," Trump  said earlier this month  to a CNN reporter regarding a possible pardon for Maxwell. "I wouldn't consider it or not consider — I don't know anything about it. I will speak to the DOJ." Wallace said those who doubt Maxwell's involvement in the abuse, "will get their answers in this book." "She was not on the sidelines," Wallace said. "She was sexually abusing herself. She was telling girls to sexually service her. She was hurting some of those girls when she was angry at them in a sexual way." Roberts said he was astounded to hear the president's stance on a possible pardon for Maxwell. "At one point he ran his campaign on the fact that he would release these [Epstein] files," Roberts said. "My sister had hope that he would. She was hopeful." 5. Giuffre's story is larger than the narrative of sex abuse Wallace said Epstein was not an anomaly or "some super apex predator," but rather a sign of our times. "This is part of our culture," she said. "Wealthy people, powerful people get to treat people less wealthy terribly," she said. "And I think that's why it resonates beyond sexual abuse. I think people are sick of it." This article discusses suicide. If you or someone you know is struggling or in crisis,  call or text 988, the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline.  The radio version of this interview was produced by Phil Harrell and Taylor Haney. The digital version was edited by Majd Al-Waheidi. 
         
         Transcript 
         LEILA FADEL, HOST:   There's a famous picture that most of the world would recognize. It's of now-disgraced Prince Andrew with his hand around the waist of a teen girl in a pink top and jeans. That was Virginia Roberts Giuffre. As an adult, she was one of the most outspoken survivors of abuse at the hands of Jeffrey Epstein and convicted sex offender Ghislaine Maxwell. Prince Andrew was one of many powerful men that Giuffre says she was trafficked to by the wealthy pair. On Friday, Buckingham Palace released a statement from Prince Andrew. It said he had given up his title as Duke of York amid fresh scrutiny of the allegations, which he has consistently denied. Virginia wrote about this and all she endured in a book called "Nobody's Girl." But before it was published, she died by suicide in the spring. I spoke to Amy Wallace, her collaborator on the book, along with her brother Sky Roberts. And a warning - sexual abuse and suicide come up in our conversation. The book opens with the last email Wallace received from Virginia. AMY WALLACE: She basically just said, in the case of my passing, I need and want this book to be published - not just for me, but for all survivors. FADEL: Sky, you're written about so lovingly. You were her baby brother. You were with her in Australia near the end of her life. What do you want the world to know about your sister? SKY ROBERTS: I look at my sister as a hero. FADEL: Amy, I want to talk more about the beginning of the book and her childhood. The book goes back much further, to abuses that she first encountered at - what? - 7 years old? If you could just talk about what it was like for Virginia to write in such detail. WALLACE: Well, I mean, the entire book is an exercise in trying to show her in all her complexity. FADEL: Yes. WALLACE: And when we began unpacking all of that, she had always said, I was abused by a family friend. And that was... FADEL: Yeah. WALLACE: ...True, as far as it went. But she had also been abused by her own father. As we worked on the book, she said, how can I be calling out all these people who came later - Epstein, Maxwell, all of their wealthy and influential friends who she was trafficked to - and not acknowledge or name the original betrayer of me, the original abuser of me? And you note in the book that you reached out to her father. Actually, there's a lot of meticulous reporting done in this, reaching out to everybody she's accused, and he's continued to deny that. Throughout Virginia's pages, she writes about not being believed - about how it made her feel worthless as a child and teen, about the way she was broken down and used. ROBERTS: Our sister was very transparent with us, especially towards the end of her relationship, about the abuse that she was incurring for 22 years throughout her marriage, on and off. She fought off Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, and she was very proud of that with her survivor sisters. She wanted to continue that advocacy work. FADEL: At the end of her life, Sky was with her. ROBERTS: She was laughing when we were there 'cause the chickens would chase me around, and we nicknamed one Raptor at one point. articles.title: What experts say 'A House of Dynamite' gets wrong (and right) about nuclear war
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article critiques the film 'A House of Dynamite,' directed by Kathryn Bigalow, for its portrayal of a single nuclear missile attack on the U.S. Experts argue that such a scenario is unrealistic, as nuclear conflicts more often escalate from conventional crises. The film's depiction of missile defense at Fort Greely is plausible but limited, and the nuclear command structure, including the doomsday Zoom call and use of the 'football,' is largely accurate. Experts stress that in a real-world situation, leaders would likely wait to verify an attack before retaliating, and that the world is currently at a critical juncture due to expanding nuclear arsenals and the expiration of key U.S.-Russia arms control agreements. The film is thus seen as a valuable tool for raising public awareness about the risks of nuclear war and the need for arms control and policy reform.
keyTakeAways: The film 'A House of Dynamite' depicts a single nuclear missile threat to the U.S., which experts say is unlikely in reality — nuclear wars more commonly escalate from conventional conflicts or periods of heightened tension between powers.
Real-world nuclear attacks are expected to involve multiple warheads and be designed to disable U.S. counterstrike capabilities, not isolated, surprise strikes.

The missile defense system (Ground-based Midcourse Defense at Fort Greely) is shown as having a plausible but limited success rate; experts note that current systems are vulnerable to multiple warheads or decoys and would likely fail against large-scale attacks.

The doomsday Zoom call — a video conference among military and political leaders — is a realistic reflection of actual U.S. nuclear command protocols, including the use of the 'football' (a container with pre-set nuclear retaliation options).

In a real scenario, the president would likely not launch a retaliatory strike immediately due to uncertainty over the attacker and the need to verify an actual attack (e.g., through intelligence attribution).

The film's portrayal of nuclear decision-making highlights human dilemmas, such as officials using personal devices in classified settings, which reflects the emotional and practical pressures of nuclear command.

Experts emphasize that the world is currently in a critical moment due to expanding nuclear arsenals by the U.S., Russia, and China, and the impending end of key arms control agreements, making films like 'A House of Dynamite' a necessary tool for public awareness and policy reflection.

articles.content:
Here's what experts say 'A House of Dynamite' gets wrong (and right) about nuclear war 
         By Geoff Brumfiel 
        
           Friday, October 24, 2025 • 5:01 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         This essay contains spoilers for the film  A House of Dynamite . In the opening minutes of Kathryn Bigalow's latest film,  A House of Dynamite , the unthinkable happens — a single nuclear warhead is lobbed from somewhere in the Pacific towards the U.S. mainland. America's leadership has less than half an hour to decide whether to order a massive nuclear counterstrike. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       What follows is a story told from the perspective of the politicians, generals, and bureaucrats in charge of the nation's nuclear war machine. It unfolds in near real time, and provides an unflinching look at the decisions that would need to be made if such a strike ever occurred. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Very few Americans  think about  nuclear war  these days, but the small cadre of experts who do have split views about  A House of Dynamite . Here's a taste of what they felt it got right, and wrong. The nuclear attack was (probably) not the most realistic As the film opens, it appears to be a relatively normal day. The nation's state of nuclear readiness, otherwise known as its defense readiness condition or "DEFCON", appears to be set to "4", just one notch above its lowest level. Then, seemingly out of nowhere the missile appears on screens, headed towards the central U.S. Hollywood loves to depict nuclear wars as starting with a bolt from the blue. But many experts think nuclear war is more likely to escalate out of  a conventional conflict  or during a time of heightened tensions between nuclear powers. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "The real dangers of nuclear war mainly have to do with escalation from some non-nuclear crisis that evolves to armed conflict," said Matthew Bunn, who studies nuclear issues at the Harvard Kennedy School. Moreover, Bunn added, a surprise attack, if it did happen, would likely involve multiple warheads and be designed to blunt the United States' ability to launch a nuclear counterattack: "No one in their right mind is going to fire ONE missile at a major U.S. city out of a clear blue sky." The depiction of the America's missile defenses isn't perfect As the warhead flies towards its target, America's missile defenses swing into action. As it happens, the missile's trajectory makes it a good candidate for interception by the nation's  Ground-based Midcourse Defense system  at Fort Greely, Alaska. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Fort Greely fires two interceptors at the missile. The first one fails and the second one misses, much to the consternation of those soldiers operating the system and the officials who paid for it. The failure of interceptors has happened before, said Jeffrey Lewis, a scholar of global security at Middlebury College who studies missile defenses. And just one interceptor has a slightly better than 50/50 chance of hitting, making the scenario plausible. But Lewis said he thinks current rules call for launching at least four, rather than two, interceptor missiles at a threat. That would considerably increase the odds. "I do think the system in Alaska — if all it had to do was hit one lonely missile fired all by itself — I think they have a good chance of that," he said. Lewis added that there are many scenarios where missile defense would likely fail. Existing missiles can carry multiple warheads or decoys, and many nuclear powers are developing new weapons that could evade defenses. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "The real problem is not when you're defending against one or two, it's when you're trying to defend against a hundred or a thousand," he said. Today's missile defense system wouldn't work, and even a vastly expanded system, like  President Trump's proposed Golden Dome , could likely be overwhelmed. The doomsday Zoom call is real The bulk of the movie revolves around a video conference between military officials, the president (played by Idris Elba), and the secretary of defense (played by Jared Harris). That call is all too real, according to Stephen Schwartz, an independent scholar who has extensively researched the history of America's nuclear command systems. If a missile is detected, then "the National Military Command Center (NMCC) convenes a Threat Assessment Conference Call with multiple lower level duty officers," Schwartz said. "If the threat is validated, it becomes a Missile Attack Conference Call joined by more senior officials (and the president, if a senior conferee requests it)." The different rooms  from which the calls are made were "scarily authentic," said Rose Gottemoeller, a professor at Stanford University who served as the Deputy Secretary General of NATO from 2016-2019 and previously oversaw arms control at the State Department. "The situation room at the White House, for example, was absolutely pitch perfect," she said. The same goes for the movie's depiction of the deep underground command site at U.S. Strategic Command in Omaha, Neb. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Schwartz also praised the representation of the president's options for nuclear retaliation, which are carried by a military officer in a brown satchel, known as  the "football."  It really does travel with the president everywhere he goes, as a reminder that the U.S. could retaliate against a nuclear strike at any time. "The 'Football' looked exactly as it should and that the Presidential Decision Handbook [which lists the pre-set options for a nuclear strike] was a reasonable-looking facsimile," he said. Those on the conference call would likely face very human dilemmas, and that might lead them to deviate from the rules, added Erin Dumbacher, an expert in nuclear policy at the Council on Foreign Relations. "You see them at some point in time break the rules and bring their cell phones into the classified area because they have real families and real personal lives." The president would have a choice the film never discusses As the clock ticks down, the U.S. president faces an impossible decision about how to respond to what looks like it will be a direct nuclear blow to Chicago. His aide carrying the football (Jonah Hauer-King), recommends a forceful counterstrike — the "well done" option, as he describes it. But in fact, the president would probably be advised to ride out the attack, Lewis said. U.S. forces are capable of launching their missiles "on warning" before an attacker's missiles arrive, but the country's nuclear doctrine actually emphasizes what's known as a "second strike" capability. That would allow it to strike back even if it were hit with a nuclear attack much larger than the one in the movie. Moreover, in the film, the U.S. is unsure who fired the warhead, so is no clear adversary to hit back at. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "It made no sense to me," Lewis said. In a real-world scenario, it is more likely the president and his commanders would wait to see what happened to Chicago. (One possibility raised by several experts NPR spoke to was that the entire launch was a false alarm or spoofed as part of a cyberattack.) If a weapon did detonate over Chicago, "it won't be very long before the national labs and the intelligence community can attribute the [nuclear] material to a particular country," Lewis said. Then the president could make a more considered decision about how to respond. The timing of the movie could not be better While experts quibbled over some of the details, they agreed that the world needs to be thinking more about the possibility of nuclear war. China, Russia and the United States are expanding and upgrading their arsenals with new weapons and more of them. And early next year, the last surviving arms control treaty between the U.S. and Russia will expire. The film lays bare the tensions and paradoxes of nuclear deterrence, said Daryl Kimball, executive director of the Arms Control Association, which advocates for nuclear arms control. " A House of Dynamite  should lead us all to consider: 'what can we do now, what must change, to avoid the many different scenarios that could lead us down the road to a nuclear war?'"

articles.title: P&G to Increase Prices in Part Due to Tariffs as Shoppers Remain Cautious and Delay Purchases
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Procter & Gamble reported stronger-than-expected financial results for its fiscal first quarter, with $4.75 billion in revenue and $1.95 per share earnings, surpassing Wall Street’s estimates. The company attributes this performance to resilient demand in its beauty and grooming segments, while also revising its tariff cost forecast for fiscal 2026 from $800 million to $400 million in after-tax expenses. This shift reflects a reduced impact of President Donald Trump’s tariffs, which previously prompted P&G to raise prices on about a quarter of its U.S. products and reevaluate sourcing and formulation strategies. Despite ongoing trade uncertainties—highlighted by Trump’s recent decision to end trade negotiations with Canada—P&G maintains full-year earnings guidance of $6.83 to $7.09 per share and sales growth guidance of 1% to 5%, signaling continued confidence in its business model amid global economic volatility.
keyTakeAways: Procter & Gamble reported stronger-than-expected earnings for the fiscal first quarter, with $4.75 billion in revenue and $1.95 per share earnings, exceeding analyst expectations.
After removing restructuring costs, earnings reached $1.99 per share, reflecting improved performance and operational efficiency.
Revenue increased to $22.39 billion, surpassing Wall Street's estimate of $22.15 billion, with 6% growth in the beauty segment and 5% growth in grooming sales.
The company revised its forecast for tariff-related after-tax costs in fiscal 2026 from $800 million to $400 million, indicating a reduced impact of trade policies.
P&G raised prices on about a quarter of its U.S. products in July due to higher costs from President Donald Trump’s tariffs, with a focus on offering improved product features.
The company has been actively adapting to tariffs by shifting sourcing and reformulating products to avoid duty costs.
Despite ongoing uncertainty, P&G maintains full-year earnings guidance between $6.83 and $7.09 per share and sales growth guidance of 1% to 5%.

Tariff-related uncertainty remains a significant factor in global trade, especially given the recent announcement by President Donald Trump ending all trade negotiations with Canada over a television ad criticizing U.S. tariffs.

articles.title: Picasso’s Portrait of Dora Maar Sells for $37 Million at Paris Auction
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A vivid portrait of Dora Maar by Picasso, painted in 1943 and previously hidden in a private family collection since 1944, sold at a Paris auction for 32 million euros, surpassing expectations and sparking global interest. The painting, part of Picasso’s 'Woman in a Hat' series, captures a pivotal emotional moment as the artist’s relationship with Maar was coming to an end. Experts praised its vibrant colors and raw condition, noting it was never varnished and thus retains its original brilliance. Though the sale was emotionally resonant and commercially successful, it did not break the record for the most expensive Picasso work, which remains the 2015 sale of 'Les Femmes d’Alger' for $179.4 million. The event underscores the enduring cultural and emotional significance of Picasso’s personal relationships in shaping his legacy.
keyTakeAways: The portrait of Dora Maar by Picasso, painted in 1943, sold for 32 million euros ($37 million) at auction in Paris, surpassing expectations.
The painting, titled 'Bust of a Woman with a Flowered Hat (Dora Maar)', is part of Picasso’s 'Woman in a Hat' series and depicts the artist’s muse and partner during a period of emotional transition.
The work had been hidden in private family collection since 1944 and was only seen in a black-and-white photograph prior to the auction.
The sale was described as emotionally significant, reflecting the bittersweet end of Picasso’s relationship with Dora Maar, who was seen as containing tears in the portrait.
The painting is noted for its vivid colors and raw, unvarnished condition, with experts praising its expressive depth and chromatic range.
The sale was a global sensation, with interest from major markets including the United States, Asia, and Europe.
Although the sale exceeded estimates, it did not surpass Picasso’s most expensive work sold — 'Les Femmes d’Alger' (sold for $179.4 million in 2015) or 'Femme à la montre' ($139.4 million in 2023).

articles.title: Russian military planes briefly violate Lithuanian airspace, sparks diplomatic fallout
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 23, 2025, Russian military aircraft — a Su-30 fighter jet and an IL-78 refueling aircraft — briefly entered Lithuanian airspace, prompting President Gitanas Nausėda to condemn the move as a blatant violation of international law and territorial integrity. Lithuania claims the planes were conducting refueling exercises near the Russian exclave of Kaliningrad, while Russia's defense ministry denies the intrusion, stating the flights were routine and compliant with international rules. In response, Lithuania plans to summon Russian embassy representatives in Vilnius. The incident has heightened concerns about Russia’s military activities in the Baltic region and is seen as part of a broader effort by Russian officials, possibly under Vladimir Putin, to test NATO’s defensive readiness. This event occurs amid ongoing tensions from Russia’s war in Ukraine and within the context of the EU’s 'Readiness 2030' plan, which aims to strengthen Europe’s ability to defend itself by 2030. Spanish fighter jets were scrambled as part of NATO’s air policing mission to respond to the intrusion.
keyTakeAways: Russian military aircraft briefly entered Lithuanian airspace on October 23, 2025, prompting strong condemnation from President Gitanas Nausėda.
Lithuania claims that two Russian planes — a Su-30 fighter jet and an IL-78 refueling aircraft — flew into its airspace for about 18 seconds, covering approximately 700 meters.
The Russian Defense Ministry denies the violation, stating that the Su-30 jets were conducting training flights over Kaliningrad in compliance with international rules.
The incident is seen as a test of NATO’s defensive readiness, with Baltic nations already on heightened alert due to Russia’s ongoing aggression in Ukraine.
Lithuania plans to summon Russian embassy representatives in Vilnius to protest the airspace breach.
Two Spanish fighter jets were scrambled during the incident as part of NATO’s air policing mission.
This event occurs in the context of broader geopolitical tensions, with some leaders accusing Vladimir Putin of conducting a hybrid war against Europe.
The incident reinforces the urgency of the EU’s 'Readiness 2030' plan, which aims to ensure Europe can defend itself against external threats by 2030.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa Threatens Caribbean with Catastrophic Flooding and Hurricane Conditions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, the 13th named storm of the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season, is nearly stationary in the central Caribbean and is forecast to strengthen into a major hurricane, potentially reaching Category 4 status. The storm is expected to move over Jamaica and affect southwest Haiti and the southern Dominican Republic, where up to 35 inches of rain could cause catastrophic flooding and landslides. The U.S. National Hurricane Center and AccuWeather have warned that the storm's slow movement could result in prolonged exposure to dangerous weather, increasing the risk of a humanitarian disaster. At least three people have died in Haiti, and one person died and one is missing in the Dominican Republic due to storm-related incidents. Emergency measures, including school and government office closures, shelter activations, and mandatory evacuations, have been implemented. The storm is also projected to impact eastern Cuba as a major hurricane by early Wednesday. The article underscores the urgent need for public preparedness and international attention due to the severity and duration of the storm’s impacts.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Melissa is expected to strengthen into a hurricane and potentially reach Category 4 status by Monday, due to its slow movement over the Caribbean.
The storm poses a significant risk of catastrophic flooding and landslides, particularly in southwest Haiti and Jamaica, where rainfall could exceed 35 inches (89 cm) in some areas.
At least three people have died in Haiti, with one death and one missing reported in the Dominican Republic, due to landslides and flooding.

Jamaica and the southern Dominican Republic have implemented emergency measures, including school and government office closures, activation of over 650 shelters, and mandatory evacuations in affected areas.
The storm’s slow movement is considered a 'slow-motion disaster' with the potential to cause prolonged exposure to dangerous weather conditions and a humanitarian crisis.

The U.S. National Hurricane Center and AccuWeather experts have issued warnings about the severity of the situation, emphasizing that the ground is already saturated from prior rainfall, increasing flood risk.

articles.title: U.S. Stocks Hit Records Amid Hopeful Inflation Data and AI Growth
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. stock markets hit record highs on Friday following a more favorable inflation report, which eased concerns for households and signaled potential for further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq all set new all-time highs, driven by strong corporate earnings, particularly from Ford, Intel, and Procter & Gamble. Technology stocks surged due to AI-driven demand, with Google benefiting from an expansion by Anthropic into its cloud infrastructure. Despite market concerns about stock overvaluation and bank risk, investor sentiment improved as inflation data and labor market dynamics suggested a shift toward easing monetary policy. Gold prices had previously surged but have since stalled, reflecting investor caution. The Federal Reserve’s focus is now on labor market conditions, not inflation, with expectations of two more rate cuts in the near term. Meanwhile, geopolitical tensions, including potential U.S.-China trade conflicts, were briefly a market concern but have eased with upcoming diplomatic talks between President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping.
keyTakeAways: U.S. stocks reached new all-time highs due to a more favorable inflation report, reducing fears of continued economic pain for households and signaling potential further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
The Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates may be influenced by labor market concerns, not inflation, suggesting a shift in policy focus toward job market stability.
Stronger-than-expected profits from major U.S. companies like Ford, Intel, and Procter & Gamble contributed to stock gains, especially in technology and consumer goods sectors.
Google and AI-related stocks surged following an expansion announcement by Anthropic to use Google Cloud for its AI chatbot, reflecting the broader market rally driven by AI innovation.
Gold prices, though recently in a correction phase, were previously on a strong upward trend due to concerns over global government debt and inflation, which continue to influence investor sentiment.
Despite positive earnings, market concerns persist about overvaluation, excessive risk-taking by banks, and geopolitical tensions, such as those stemming from potential U.S.-China tariff threats.

articles.title: Federal Indictment of NBA Figures Raises Questions Over Legalized Sports Gambling
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal indictment has led to the arrest of over 30 individuals, including NBA players Terry Rozier and Portland Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups, on charges of illegal sports betting. The case centers on allegations that individuals exploited private player information to place illegal prop bets, particularly on player performance statistics. This comes amid the rapid expansion of legal sports betting since 2018, when the Supreme Court overturned PASPA, enabling widespread betting across 38 states. The NBA and other leagues are accused of enabling gambling through data-sharing deals with companies like Sportradar and FanDuel, which provide real-time stats used for micro-betting. While legal betting generates revenue and improves fraud detection, experts warn of serious social consequences, including addiction and financial harm to vulnerable groups like young men in low-income communities. The incident has sparked debate over regulation, transparency, and the ethical responsibilities of professional sports organizations in a growing gambling ecosystem.
keyTakeAways: The expansion of legalized sports betting across 38 U.S. states and D.C. has normalized gambling in sports, with ads and live betting tickers now common during broadcasts.
Professional sports leagues, including the NBA and NFL, are accused of enabling illegal betting through data-sharing agreements that allow micro-betting on player performance.
The indictment of Terry Rozier and Chauncey Billups raises concerns about insider access to player information and potential collusion to manipulate prop bets.
Experts warn that while legal betting has benefits like state revenue and fraud detection, it also promotes addictive behaviors, especially among young men in low-income communities.
The NBA’s partnership with Sportradar and data-sharing with platforms like FanDuel enables real-time stats used for betting, raising ethical and regulatory questions.
Despite industry claims of security measures, experts note that the sheer volume of micro-bets and player data makes manipulation harder to detect and more common.
The NFL, NBA, MLB, and NHL all prohibit employees from betting on their own games, yet the line between legal and illegal activity remains blurred.

articles.title: Ontario Pauses Anti-Tariff Ads After Trump Ends Trade Talks
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ontario Premier Doug Ford has paused a taxpayer-funded anti-tariff advertising campaign that used excerpts from former President Ronald Reagan’s 1987 radio address on trade, following U.S. President Donald Trump’s decision to end all trade negotiations with Canada. Trump accused the Canadian ads of being fake and of misleadingly editing Reagan’s speech, claiming it was an attempt to influence a U.S. Supreme Court ruling on tariffs. Ford, who sees the ad as a legitimate and effective way to promote a pro-trade message, stated that the campaign would continue during the first two World Series games. Canadian officials, including Prime Minister Mark Carney, acknowledge the shift in U.S. trade policy but emphasize their focus on domestic economic strategies. Critics, including political analysts and former ministers, have questioned the ad’s effectiveness, with some, like Daniel Béland, arguing it has backfired and intensified trade tensions. The incident underscores a deepening diplomatic rift between Canada and the United States over trade policy and the use of media to influence public opinion.
keyTakeAways: Ontario Premier Doug Ford has paused a taxpayer-funded anti-tariff advertising campaign in response to U.S. President Donald Trump ending trade negotiations with Canada.
Trump accused Canada of misrepresenting Ronald Reagan’s 1987 radio address about tariffs, claiming the ad was 'fake' and a fraudulent attempt to influence U.S. policy.
The ad, which features Reagan’s original anti-tariff message, was designed to criticize U.S. tariffs and promote a pro-trade economy, but has triggered a trade conflict between Canada and the U.S.

Canadian officials, including Prime Minister Mark Carney, acknowledge the shift in U.S. trade policy but emphasize their focus on controlling domestic exports and maintaining international trade partnerships.
Trump’s rhetoric, including threatening Canada with becoming the '51st state,' has intensified trade tensions and raised concerns about sovereignty and economic stability.
The ad campaign will continue to air during the first World Series games, suggesting a strategic effort to reach American audiences during high-profile cultural events.
Canadian political allies, including Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew and British Columbia Premier David Eby, publicly support the campaign, while experts like Daniel Béland criticize it as a backfire.
Former Conservative minister Jason Kenney defends the ad as a legitimate replay of Reagan’s actual speech and criticizes the Reagan Foundation's response to Trump’s claims.

articles.title: DOJ to Send Federal Election Observers to California and New Jersey Amid Political Tensions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Department of Justice is preparing to deploy federal election observers to Passaic County, New Jersey, and five California counties — Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside, and Fresno — ahead of off-year elections on November 4. The move follows requests from Republican parties in both states, citing concerns about irregularities and fraud, particularly in key swing areas. California’s vote includes a redistricting initiative that could add up to five Democratic congressional seats ahead of 2026 midterms, while New Jersey’s governor’s race in Passaic County is seen as pivotal. However, Democrats and civil rights experts argue the DOJ has no legal standing to intervene in state-only elections and that the action appears to be a politically motivated intimidation tactic, especially given the absence of federal races and the lack of proven fraud. The DOJ maintains that its role is to ensure transparency, ballot security, and compliance with civil rights laws, but experts caution that federal monitoring does not impact voter behavior or confidence when observers are strictly non-interacting.
keyTakeAways: The Department of Justice is sending federal election observers to California and New Jersey to monitor voting processes, citing transparency and compliance with federal law.

The move follows requests from Republican parties in both states, which claim irregularities and voter fraud concerns, especially in key counties like Passaic County, New Jersey, and Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside, and Fresno, California.
California's election involves a redistricting initiative that could add up to five Democratic seats in the U.S. House, making it politically sensitive and a target of federal scrutiny.
New Jersey’s governor’s race is in a competitive, swing county (Passaic) with a significant Latino population, raising concerns about vote integrity and potential voter suppression.

Democrats and civil rights experts argue that the DOJ’s intervention lacks legal standing and appears to be a political intimidation tactic, especially in the absence of federal races or voter discrimination claims.
The DOJ has previously focused on election integrity in cases involving racial discrimination, but the current action is being challenged as overreach into state-specific elections.

Despite claims of fraud, there is no evidence of widespread fraud, and experts note that election observers do not typically interact with voters or ballot counts and thus do not affect voter turnout or confidence.

articles.title: Supreme Court's 2018 Sports Betting Ruling Back in Spotlight After Mafia-Linked Betting Scandals
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In 2018, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (PASPA), ruling that Congress violated the Tenth Amendment by banning states from legalizing sports betting. This decision opened the door for a multi-billion-dollar sports betting industry. However, the ruling is now being re-examined due to recent arrests of over 30 individuals—including an NBA player and coach—allegedly involved in criminal schemes to rig sports bets and poker games linked to Mafia families. The Court’s majority opinion, authored by Justice Samuel Alito and joined by Chief Justice John Roberts and several others, emphasized that Congress could not prohibit states from authorizing sports gambling without infringing on state sovereignty. Dissenting justices, including Ruth Bader Ginsburg, argued for a more targeted approach, preserving provisions against private gambling schemes. Despite the legal shift, opponents such as the NCAA, major sports leagues, and the Trump administration have voiced concerns about corruption and the integrity of sports. Historical scandals like the Black Sox Scandal and point-shaving cases are cited to illustrate the longstanding fears surrounding sports betting’s impact on fair competition.
keyTakeAways: The 2018 Supreme Court decision invalidated the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (PASPA), allowing states to legalize sports betting, which has since grown into a multi-billion-dollar industry.

Despite the legal opening, concerns about corruption persist, as seen in recent arrests of over 30 individuals, including an NBA player and coach, accused of rigging bets and poker games involving Mafia families.

The Supreme Court ruled that Congress violated the Tenth Amendment by banning states from authorizing sports betting, as the law did not criminalize betting itself but prohibited state-level authorization.
Dissenting justices argued that the court should have preserved the provision regulating private gambling schemes, suggesting a more targeted approach.
Major sports leagues, the NCAA, and the Trump administration opposed the ruling, citing risks to game integrity and potential for corruption.
The decision was controversial, with references to historical scandals like the Black Sox Scandal and the point-shaving scandals, highlighting longstanding fears about sports integrity.

articles.title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Following a public threat from U.S. President Donald Trump to impose sanctions on countries supporting climate action, the International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed formal approval of its Net Zero Framework (NZF) by 12 months. The NZF, which would have introduced a global carbon pricing system charging ships $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emissions, was originally approved in April 2025. Despite support from major economies like China, the EU, Brazil, and Britain, the vote was delayed due to Trump’s aggressive stance, which included threats of visa restrictions and port levies. Countries like Argentina and Singapore, previously supportive, also shifted their positions. The decision undermines international efforts to reduce shipping emissions, which contribute significantly to climate change and are already affecting maritime safety. Industry leaders and climate advocates, including Vanuatu’s minister and the International Chamber of Shipping, have expressed disappointment, emphasizing the need for clarity and consistency to enable investment in decarbonization technologies such as ammonia and methanol fuels or special sails.

Title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions

Members of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) have voted to postpone approving a plan to curb shipping emissions, after United States President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions on countries that supported the measure.

The vote on Friday set back plans to regulate the shipping industry’s contributions to climate change by at least 12 months, even though the Net Zero Framework (NZF) had already been approved by members of the London-based IMO, a United Nations body,  in April .

The decision to formally delay adopting the framework until late next year came a day after President Trump took to his Truth Social platform, saying: “I am outraged that the International Maritime Organization is voting in London this week to pass a global Carbon Tax.”

“The United States will NOT stand for this Global Green New Scam Tax on Shipping,” he said, telling countries to vote against the plan.

Washington also threatened to impose sanctions, visa restrictions and port levies on countries that supported the deal.

In advance of this week’s meeting in London, about 63 IMO members who had voted for the plan in April were expected to maintain their support for curbs on emissions, and others were expected to join the initiative to formally approve the framework.

Following Trump’s social media threat, delegates in London instead voted on a hastily arranged resolution to push back proceedings on the matter, which passed by 57 votes to 49.

The IMO, which comprises 176 member countries, is responsible for regulating the safety and security of international shipping and preventing pollution on the high seas.

Since returning to power in January, Trump has focused on reversing Washington’s course on climate change, encouraging fossil fuel use by deregulation, cutting funding for  clean energy projects  and promising businesses to  “drill, baby drill”.

A spokesman for UN chief Antonio Guterres called Friday’s decisions “a missed opportunity for member states to place the shipping sector on a clear, credible path towards net zero emissions”.

The International Chamber of Shipping, representing more than 80 percent of the world’s fleet, also expressed disappointment.

“Industry needs clarity to be able to make the investments needed to decarbonise the maritime sector,” the chamber’s Secretary-General Thomas Kazakos said in a statement.

Disappointed, but still very much Committed!  https://t.co/7P192kAvCx

— Thomas A. Kazakos (@ThomasKazakos)  October 17, 2025

Ralph Regenvanu, the minister for climate change for Vanuatu, said the decision to delay the vote by 12 months was “unacceptable given the urgency we face in light of accelerating climate change”.

“But we know that we have  international law  on our side and will continue to fight for our people and the planet,” Regenvanu added.

Leading up to Friday’s decision, China, the European Union, Brazil, Britain and several other members of the IMO had reaffirmed their support.

Countries that opposed the measures included  Russia  and Saudi Arabia.

A Russian delegate described the proceedings as “chaos” as he addressed the plenary on Friday after talks had lasted into the early hours.

Argentina and Singapore, two countries that had previously voted in support of the framework in April, were among those that voted to postpone introducing it this week.

If it had been formally adopted this week, the Net Zero Framework (NZF) would have been the first global carbon-pricing system, charging ships a penalty of $380 per metric tonne on every extra tonne of CO2-equivalent they emit while rewarding vessels that reduce their emissions by using alternatives.

The framework plan is intended to help the IMO reach its target of cutting net emissions from international shipping by 20 percent by 2030 and eliminating them by 2050.

Climate change is already beginning to affect shipping and the safety of seafarers, including by changing  ocean currents  and causing more frequent and  severe storms .

Proposals to reduce reliance on dirtier bunker fuel in the shipping industry include using ammonia and methanol, as well as fitting cargo ships with special sails.

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, the first named storm of the Caribbean season this year, is threatening multiple Caribbean islands with dangerous rainfall, landslides, and flooding. With maximum sustained winds of 50mph and a slow movement westward, the storm is currently centered south-southwest of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and south-southeast of Kingston, Jamaica. Heavy rain is expected in Jamaica’s eastern region, southern Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Aruba, and Puerto Rico, with Jamaica’s eastern region potentially receiving up to 12 inches of rain. The US National Hurricane Center forecasts that Melissa could strengthen into a hurricane by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend. This development raises serious concerns for public safety, with officials urging residents in flood-prone areas to seek higher ground. The storm is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic season, and NOAA has predicted an above-normal season with up to 18 named storms and two to five major hurricanes.

Title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert

Tropical Storm Melissa is threatening the Caribbean Sea islands with dangerous landslides and life-threatening flooding, as officials urge residents of flood-prone areas to seek higher ground and shelter.

Jamaica’s eastern region could see up to 12 inches (300mm) of rain. “Now that is significant rainfall, and that is the main thing that we should be mindful of at this time,” Evan Thompson, director of Jamaica’s Meteorological Service, said.

Similar rainfall amounts were expected for southern Haiti and the southern Dominican Republic through Saturday, with even more rain possible locally, depending on Melissa’s path later in the week.

Heavy rain was also forecast for western Jamaica, southern Hispaniola, Aruba and Puerto Rico.

Melissa had maximum sustained winds of 50mph (85km/h) and was moving west at 2mph (4km/h) late on Wednesday night, according to the US National Hurricane Center in Miami.

The slow-moving storm was centred about 335 miles (535km) south-southwest of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and some 295 miles (475km) south-southeast of Kingston, Jamaica.

The NHC said the storm could strengthen gradually in the coming days and grow into a  hurricane  by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend.

Heavy rains in the Dominican Republic have already disrupted traffic and led to the cancellation of sports events.

Melissa is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, and the first named storm to form in the Caribbean this year.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season – which runs from June 1 to November 30 – with 13 to 18 named storms.

Of those, five to nine were forecast to become hurricanes, including two to five major hurricanes, which pack winds of 111mph or greater.

articles.title: Five dead, two missing as Tropical Storm Fengshen soaks Philippines
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Fengshen caused significant damage across the Philippines in October 2025, leading to at least five deaths, two missing persons, and widespread flooding on Luzon and Mindanao. In Quezon province, a family of five was killed when a tree fell on their bamboo house in Pitogo, with one teenager surviving. Over 47,000 people evacuated to shelters, and five dams on Luzon released water to mitigate floods. Flooding also impacted Samar and Panay, with a home collapse injuring one person. In Bukidnon, a landslide caused a vehicle to fall off a highway, leaving two people missing. The storm occurs amid ongoing recovery from recent earthquakes and underscores growing climate-related disaster risks. Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. called for stronger disaster preparedness, highlighting the country’s vulnerability to extreme weather events intensified by climate change.

Title: Five dead, two missing as Tropical Storm Fengshen soaks Philippines

At least five people have been killed and two reported missing as  Tropical Storm Fengshen  sweeps through the Philippines, triggering heavy flooding on the main island of Luzon and a vast landslide on the southern island of Mindanao.

In Quezon province in the north of the country, five members of one family, including two children, were crushed to death when a tree fell on their bamboo house early on Sunday, according to Philippine disaster agency officials in the town of Pitogo, where the incident took place.

Images posted on social media by officials showed the house destroyed under the weight of a large palm tree, as a rescue team worked to remove the bodies of the family.

According to a statement shared on social media, a teenage boy was the lone survivor of the accident in Pitogo, about 153km (95 miles) southeast of the capital Manila.

More than a dozen flights were ordered cancelled by aviation authorities as Fengshen hovered over Luzon, situated just south of Manila, as of Sunday afternoon. The storm was reported to be moving west towards the South China Sea.

The AFP news agency quoted officials in southeastern Luzon as saying at least 47,000 people had left their homes for the safety of government-designated temporary shelters since Saturday. At least five dams on Luzon island opened their gates to release water on Sunday, according to the national weather agency, Pagasa.

In the central Philippines, heavy flooding was reported by officials on the islands of Samar and Panay, forcing residents to evacuate.

One person was injured in the town of Estancia on Panay Island after he was pinned down following the collapse of his wooden house, the ABS-CBN news website reported.

Rumagasa ang baha sa ilang barangay sa Calbayog City, Samar dahil sa hagupit ng bagyong  #RamilPH  sa lugar ngayong Linggo, October 19. | via Ranulfo Docdocan

(Courtesy: Reymark Espinosa)  pic.twitter.com/dJAV5eOdZo

— ABS-CBN News (@ABSCBNNews)  October 19, 2025

Translation: Raging floodwater inundated several areas of Calbayog City in Samar due to Tropical Storm Ramil [Fengshen] as of Sunday, October 19.

In the province of Bukidnon on the southern island of Mindanao, two people were reported missing after their motorised three-wheel vehicle fell off a highway following a large landslide triggered by the heavy rains.

Public works officials said the highway, which connects Bukidnon to the neighbouring Davao region, is now blocked to traffic.

On average, the Philippines is hit by about 20 storms and typhoons each year, and scientists warn that extreme weather events are becoming more powerful as the planet warms due to human-driven climate change.

Fengshen also comes as the Philippines started to recover from  a series of major earthquakes  that killed at least 87 people over the past three weeks.

In a Facebook post published on Sunday, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr said the country needs to “strengthen its disaster preparedness and response” as it is “very prone to having disasters and calamities”.

articles.title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Dutch government has taken effective control of the semiconductor company Nexperia, a global manufacturer with operations across Europe, Asia, and the US, due to serious managerial shortcomings and concerns over national economic security. The intervention, enacted under the 'Goods Availability Act' on September 30, 2025, follows an emergency hearing that identified risks linked to former CEO Zhang Xuezheng’s leadership. Nexperia, originally spun off from Philips, was acquired by the Chinese group Wingtech in 2018, raising geopolitical concerns. The Dutch government cited threats to the continuity of critical technological capabilities and the availability of semiconductors essential for European industry and AI development. As a result, the company is now restricted from relocating assets, firing executives, or making major decisions without government approval for one year. The move comes amid broader global tensions, including US-China export controls on rare-earth metals and semiconductors, and China’s own restrictions on Nexperia's Chinese operations. Wingtech has rejected the intervention as politically motivated, while the EU has pledged to coordinate with the Netherlands to protect European tech sovereignty. Nexperia has appointed Stegan Tilger as interim CEO and continues to assert confidence in maintaining daily operations.
keyTakeAways: The Dutch government intervened in Nexperia, a semiconductor manufacturer, under the Goods Availability Act due to perceived threats to critical technological capabilities and economic security.
Nexperia, originally part of Philips, was acquired by Chinese group Wingtech in 2018, raising concerns about foreign ownership and control of essential tech.
The intervention was triggered by serious managerial shortcomings under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng, leading to doubts about operational stability and continuity in Europe.
The Dutch government imposed restrictions on key decisions, asset relocation, and executive changes for one year, with the aim of preserving semiconductor production and supply chains.
The move came amid broader global tensions, including US-China export controls on semiconductors and rare-earth metals, and China’s export restrictions on Nexperia’s Chinese operations.
Wingtech dismissed the Dutch action as politically motivated and based on geopolitical bias rather than technical risk.
The EU has committed to working with the Netherlands to safeguard European technological capabilities, signaling coordinated regional responses to foreign tech control concerns.

Title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?

The Dutch government has intervened to take effective control of technology group Nexperia, which is owned by Chinese group Wingtech Technology.

The decision comes amid a growing rift between China and the West over the development of technology such as computer chips and semiconductors, which are essential components for the manufacture of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

Here is more about what the Dutch government announced, why and what happens next.

In a statement released on Sunday, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs said it had invoked the “highly exceptional” Goods Availability Act to intervene and take control of Nexperia on September 30.

The Goods Availability Act allows the Netherlands to intervene in privately owned companies in exceptional circumstances, such as if the government perceives a threat to the country’s economic security or if it is necessary to ensure that critical goods remain available.

The move followed an emergency hearing by the Dutch Enterprise Chamber on October 7, which concluded that there may be “valid reasons to doubt sound management at Nexperia under the leadership of former CEO Zhang Xuezheng”, a statement from the company said.

The Dutch Enterprise Chamber is a special division of the Amsterdam Court of Appeal, which hears corporate law cases and other matters that could have major social or financial consequences.

In its statement, the government said the intervention had been carried out “due to serious administrative shortcomings” at Nexperia, which “posed a threat to the continuity and safeguarding on Dutch and European soil of crucial technological knowledge and capabilities”.

It claimed that the intervention would ensure Nexperia’s finished and semi-finished products would remain available in case of an emergency.

The ministry added that “losing these capabilities could pose a risk to Dutch and European economic security.”

Following this intervention, it said, “the company’s regular production process can continue.”

However, it added, “Based on the order, decisions within the company can be blocked or reversed if they are (potentially) harmful to the company’s interests, its future as a Dutch and European company, and/or the preservation of this crucial value chain for Europe.”

The statement said that “involved parties” can appeal the decision in court.

Nexperia is a global semiconductor manufacturer headquartered in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. It emerged as a result of electronics group Philips’ purchase of London-based Mullard Radio Valve Company and Hamburg-based Valvo in the 1920s, ultimately forming Philips’ semiconductor operation. In 2006, Philips spun off its semiconductor division, which became NXP Semiconductors, and this was later sold to a consortium of investors led by Beijing Jianguang Asset Management (JAC Capital). Wingtech acquired Nexperia from that consortium for $3.63bn in 2018.

According to its website, Nexperia employs 12,500 people in Europe, Asia and the United States.

Nexperia’s manufacturing site spans more than 80,000 square metres (861,000dsq feet) and has the capacity to build more than 50 billion components annually. It also has sales offices and research-and-development sites in China.

On Tuesday, Nexperia announced that it had suspended Zhang, founder of Wingtech, as a director and removed him as chief executive officer (CEO). It has appointed Stegan Tilger, chief financial officer (CFO), as interim CEO.

“Due to the same serious managerial shortcomings, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs observed that Nexperia’s operations in Europe were being compromised in an unacceptable manner. This situation raised broader concerns for the Dutch government about the availability of semiconductor products critical to the European industry,” Nexperia’s statement said.

“The combination of Zhang Xuezheng’s behaviour as CEO and (indirect) shareholder, as well as concerns about the semiconductor product availability in the Netherlands and Europe, ultimately led the Dutch government to intervene with an exceptional emergency order on the basis of the Goods Availability Act.”

The statement added that the government’s order has also prohibited Nexperia from relocating company assets, firing existing executives or making important decisions without explicit government approval for one year.

Nexperia said it is confident its daily operations will continue as usual.

On October 9, China  tightened export controls  for critical rare-earth metals, citing national security interests. Foreign companies must now obtain approval from Beijing before they can export the named rare-earth metals or any products that contain them. Exporters must tell the government how the products will be used.

The US is a major consumer of Chinese rare-earth metals, which are critical for its defence industry. Following China’s announcement about new export restrictions, US President Donald Trump responded by  threatening to impose a new 100 percent trade tariff  on China.

Besides being used for the manufacture of smartphones, electric cars and weapons, rare-earth metals are also used in the manufacture of semiconductors, which are essential for the development of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

The US and its Western allies in Europe have, in recent years, passed regulations restricting China’s access to Western semiconductor technology, fearing that China could reverse-engineer and manufacture the technology, moving ahead in the technological race.

In 2022, former Democratic US President Joe Biden  restricted China’s access  to US semiconductors. The new rules extended restrictions on chipmaking tools being sold to industries which support the semiconductor supply chain. They blocked these industries from accessing US technical expertise, as well as the key components required to build the machines that produce microchips.

The US further tightened these restrictions in October 2023 and, again, in December 2024.

On September 29, 2025, the US Bureau of Industry and Security extended US export control restrictions to all groups which are at least 50 percent-owned by one or more entities on the US Entity List, a list of foreign organisations and companies believed to be participating in, or are at significant risk of participating in, activities that go against US national security or foreign policy interests. These entities are subject to sanctions, export restrictions or licensing requirements. While Nexperia itself is not on the list, Wingtech was added in December 2024.

Then, on October 4, China’s Ministry of Commerce announced export controls preventing Nexperia China and its subcontractors from exporting certain finished components and sub-assemblies made in China.

“Nexperia is actively engaging with the Chinese authorities to obtain an exemption from these restrictions and has deployed all available resources to that end,” the Nexperia statement said.

“While Nexperia has made sufficient preparations to ensure business continuity – and as the BIS rule provides for a 60-day grace period – we are confident that a solution will be found,” Nexperia said in its statement on Tuesday.

Compounding all this, earlier in the year, US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to the US. China retaliated with a tariff of 125 percent on US goods. Both countries then reduced their tariffs for 90 days in  May  to allow for trade talks. In August, the two agreed to another 90-day pause, with the most recent round of talks taking place between US and Chinese officials in Spain last month.

But the US has also imposed restrictions on most Chinese cars from being sold in the US. These include high tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles.

In addition to its standard 10 percent car import duty, the EU announced last year that it would impose a range of additional tariffs on electric vehicles, from 7.8 percent for Tesla vehicles to 35.3 percent on China’s state-owned SAIC [Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation] vehicles.

Wingtech released a social media statement saying it “firmly opposes the politicisation of commercial matters”.

In the post, it deemed the Dutch government’s move “an excessive intervention based on geopolitical bias rather than a fact-based risk assessment” that is based on the “unfounded pretext of national security”.

Shares in Wingtech have plummeted by 10 percent on the Shanghai Stock Exchange since the announcement. As a result, Wingtech was forced to explain the situation to the exchange, saying that the Dutch government’s decision “temporarily restricts” its control over Nexperia.

Beijing “consistently opposes the overstretching of national security concepts and discriminatory practices targeting companies from specific countries”, Lin Jian, spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said on Monday.

“Relevant countries should genuinely uphold market principles and avoid politicising economic and trade issues.”

The European Union has been closely coordinating with Dutch officials and will now work with the Netherlands to decide what to do next to protect important tech capabilities in Europe, according to European Commission spokesperson Olof Gill.

articles.title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details a renewed trade conflict between the United States and China, centered on a 100% tariff threat by US President Donald Trump in response to China's expanded export controls on rare earth minerals. China, which holds a near-monopoly on rare earths essential for technologies like electric vehicles and semiconductors, justified its restrictions as a response to US economic and technological targeting of Chinese industries. The US, in turn, accuses China of 'double standards' and 'trade hostility,' with Trump warning of sweeping retaliation, including export controls on critical software. This escalation comes just weeks before a scheduled meeting between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea during the APEC summit, raising concerns about a renewed trade war. Historical context reveals that the US and China have engaged in a long-standing pattern of tit-for-tat tariffs and export restrictions, beginning in 2018 and continuing through the Biden era with targeted controls on semiconductors and AI technology. Experts suggest both nations are strategically leveraging economic and technological tools to gain leverage in negotiations, with China demonstrating early strategic preparedness and the US showing greater economic resilience. The situation underscores a broader trend of great power competition where national security and economic policy are deeply intertwined, and where both sides maintain escalation tools in reserve, signaling that the conflict is more about strategic signaling than immediate economic collapse.
keyTakeAways: The US and China are engaged in a prolonged trade and technological rivalry, marked by repeated tariff hikes and export controls.
China expanded rare earth export controls in October 2025, citing US economic restrictions and national security concerns.
Trump threatened a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, 2025, in response to China’s actions, raising fears of a renewed trade war.
China views US actions as 'double standards' and claims they are targeting Chinese firms in military and technology sectors under national security justifications.
Both nations are weaponizing economic interdependence, with each using export controls and tariffs to exert pressure in diplomatic negotiations.
The upcoming meeting between Trump and Xi in South Korea is at risk due to escalating tensions, with both sides preparing strategic responses.
Experts suggest that the US has greater economic resilience due to its domestic market, while China is more vulnerable due to export-dependent growth.
The conflict reflects a broader global trend where national security and economic policy are deeply intertwined, with no clear 'saints' in great power competition.
